newsitem.title: IRAQ: Turkey says wants more trade with Iraq.
newsitem.headline: Turkey says wants more trade with Iraq.

text.p: Turkish State Minister Ahmet Cemil Tunc said his government had made efforts to end the mandate of a U.S.-led air force patrolling northern Iraq and wanted to increase trade with Baghdad to $4-5 billion a year.

"Probably it is not necessary to remind here of the efforts by the (Turkish) government to end the mandate of the (allied) forces in Turkey," Tunc said at the start of talks with Iraqi Oil Minister Amir Muhammad Rasheed.
Baghdad has been urging Ankara to end the mandate of the U.S. and British force which polices a no-fly zone in northern Iraq to guard Kurds against possible attacks by Iraqi armed forces.

Turkey's Islamist-led government made only cosmetic alterations, such as a name change, to the south Turkey-based force last year despite Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan's election pledges that his party would scrap it after coming to power.
The Turkish parliament has renewed the mandate of the force.
Tunc also said his country was ... "seeking to improve trade with Iraq to reach four to five billion dollars per year."
He did not give the present figure.
The minister said Iraq's oil-for-food deal with the United Nations was a ... "means to improve trade between Iraq and Turkey but it was not enough".

The deal, which went into effect on December 10, allows Iraq to sell $2 billion worth of oil over six months to buy urgent needs of Iraqis, suffering from stringent trade sanctions imposed after Baghdad's 1990 invasion of Kuwait.
Under the deal, Turkey has a contract to lift 75,000 barrels per day of Iraqi crude. Ankara is also selling to Iraq under the pact, pulses and vegetable oil.
Tunc said his government was also increasing cross-border trade with Baghdad. Hundreds of Turkish trucks currently cross into Iraq every day carrying vegetables, fruits and processed food.
"Concerning cross-border trade, there are serious steps to improve that," he added.
He said he would discuss several projects with Iraqi officials including a railway line between the two countries.
The Turkish minister arrived in Baghdad on Monday on the invitation of Rasheed, who was in Ankara in December.
